text: Thanks a lot! That means a lot. Anything you think I should change / add / remove? I was thinking of doing two reels an fx reel with pyro/ rbd ect and a crowd/cfx/groom reel.

I've asked a senior at work about the whole Groom/Crowd stuff; because they're quite different. CFX is closer to FX work than Crowd or possibly Groom. so if you have any muscle/CFX stuff, that's probably better in FX. As for Crowd and Groom they would personally keep them separate if you can.
So if you're applying to smaller studio, it might be worth having a "generalist" FX/CFX/Crowd reel, but for larger studios, you'd want to have a reel that focuses on the  role you're applying for. So the FX reel if it's an FX artist, or Crowd reel if it's for Crowd.
If you've just graduated though, it would be worth just having a "generalist" reel handy anyway, and to not 100% specialize until you're 100% sure
This is what someone has just said to me here, so hopefully that's helpful?

Also, if you're not "really happy" with a piece of work, it might be best not to include it. Even if it's in an area you haven't got on your reel just yet (Like a piece of Groom). You could mention in interviews you're learning, but for your showreel, you want it to show off what you consider to be your best work, stuff that shows your standard/level
I'll check the reel again when I'm not busy at work, and see if I have any comments!

That clears things up thanks. I guess I'll put all my effort into one strong reel for now. I saw your reel too by the way, awesome work! It must have been a trip to work on The Avengers. What's it like working at Outpost?
Yeah, if you get one strong reel now, then can maybe start refining a few other reels once you have a bit more work to pad them out
Hah thanks! I really enjoy it, the people are awesome (like most places). I personally prefer Bournemouth to London, so that probably sways me a bit as well
